title.narrative: Community Security and Arms Control South Sudan
Samhällssäkerhet och kontroll av vapen i Sydsudan

description.narrative:
CSAC aims to provide technical and financial support to the governmental Bureau for Community Security & Small Arms Control (BCSSAC), the South Sudan Peace & Reconciliation Commission (SSPRC) and the National Platform for Peace and Reconciliation (NPPR), in fostering dialogue, peace and reconciliation, while at the same time improving community security and strengthening broader post-conflict recovery initiatives.
It is assumed that reduced violence and improved community security will be achieved through a combination of efforts targeting both legislative reform on SALW, better government development programming, inclusive peace and reconciliation solutions involving both institutions, constituencies and communities, an increased imprint of county governments and a strengthened civil society better prepared to promote accountability and engender social cohesion.

UNDP har ansökt till Sida om finansiering på 4,8 MUSD (40 MSEK) för att genomföra projektet Community Security & Arms Control (CSAC) i Sydsudan under perioden 2015-2016.
CSAC syftar till att ge tekniskt och finansiellt stöd till statliga Bureau for Community Security and Small Arms Control (BCSSAC), South Sudan Peace & Reconciliation Commission (SSPRC) och National Platform for Peace and Reconciliatioin (NPPR), för att främja dialog, fred och försoning, samtidigt som samhällssäkerheten förbättras och bredare post-konfliktinitiativ för återhämtning stärks. Det förutsätts att minskat våld och förbättrad samhällssäkerhet kommer att uppnås genom en kombination av insatser riktade mot lagstiftningsreformer kring små och lätta vapen, bättre utvecklingsprogrammering från regeringen, inkluderande freds- och försoningslösningar som omfattar både institutioner och samhällen, ett större avtryck från lokal förvaltning och ett stärkt civilt samhälle bättre förberett för att främja ansvarstagande och skapa social sammanhållning. Det är framförallt arbetet med det civila samhället som Sida kommer att stödja, vilket fokuserar på olika typer av dialoger mellan det civila samhället/civila aktörer och regeringen på både lokal och nationell nivå, för förbättrad samhällssäkerhet. I det här arbetet kommer organisationer som arbetar för kvinnor och ungdomar att prioriteras.
Insatsens totala budget för 2015-2016 är USD 17,628,703, varav UNDP:s egen finansiering är USD 680,500. Resterande medel kommer från DFID (USD 6,872,579), Norge (USD 824,784), Schweiz (USD 100 000) utöver de förväntade medlen från Sida (USD 4,800,000 dvs. 40 000 000 SEK). Omkring USD 4,350,840 av budgeten (33 %) är för närvarande ofinansierad.
Violence is reduced and community security improves.

tag.narrative: 16.4 - By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.
16.4 - Till 2030 avsevärt minska de olagliga finansiella flödena och vapenflödena, öka möjligheterna att återvinna och återfå stulna tillgångar samt bekämpa alla former av organiserad brottslighet.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: This Completion Memo can be read together with the Statement on Report (May 2018). The following project reports provide the main basis for information on results: CSAC Final Report (April 2015-June 2017), reporting on the Sida funded output 5 CSAC Final report (March 2011-April 2017), reporting on the CSAC project as a whole The CSAC Summative Evaluation, final report (May 2017) Some examples of results achieved during the project include: * The passing of the Firearms Act "Small Arms and Light Weapons" bill including the development of an implementation roadmap. * Strengthened community resilience to conflict by combatting tensions along ethnic and political lines, building more shock responsive communities including for IDPs. * In the "Leave No One Behind" agenda, the added CSO component of the project managed to reach into areas previously unattained and enhance sustainability in doing so (funded by Sida). * Working with CSOs at community level across divides and building capacity (funded by Sida). * Decreased level of violence following the establishment of livestock patrol in previously known Jonglei state. Same trends have been visible in Lakes state, where there has been a shift from cattle "raids" to cattle "theft" and large scale communal conflict to petty crimes. * Training for women in conflict analysis and mediation (funded by Sida). * Through two women peace initiatives, a women peace dialogue process and the commemoration of the International Day of Peace, 3,450 women were reached with peace messages at national and subnational level (funded by Sida). Some challenges reported include: * The creation of 32 states reinforced tensions along ethnic lines, creating a more volatile context and challenges the establishment of a national infrastructure for peace. * The efforts on infrastructure (prisons and police posts) have not been sustainable due to the deteriorating context. * In relation to the Do No Harm discourse, the provision of water facilities (boreholes and haffirs for human and animal consumption) was initially an important element of the conflict sensitivity initiative as conflict over water is a major issue in Lakes, Jonglei and Eastern Equatoria. However, there is a need to maintain these facilities, not to create sources of conflict. * Staggering inflation has made South Sudan an extremely costly context, in some instances making the implementing partner (UNDP) conduct its work using US dollars.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
